Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Introductory concepts regarding derivatives and integrals.
A much better understanding of basic calculus and some applications.
I learned a lot more about the basics of calculus.
Strengths are the layout of the course. Weaknesses are the inexperience of the faculty with engaging students.
Certain instructors seemed better prepared than others. It would have been nice to have some consistency.
The course itself was very structured. I didn't like how Problem Sets were worth so much of our grade.
I think this course could be better organized in regards to homework and homework expectations.

The webassign homework often felt more like busy work, and when submitting answers the website would be finicky and take off points from answers that were the same but typed in differently (ie imperfect fractions, or mixed numbers).
I would recommend if you need basic knowledge of calculus but do not take it for fun.
I would only recommend it if they needed the credit. There was so many haphazard problem sets and oddball webassigns.
Although it is not the most interesting, I would recommend this course to a student looking for a QR credit.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless it was for a requirement.
